text:
How the Doctor Dream movie combines drama and true horror by Stephen King
07 Nov 2019, 17:30 by Alexei Khromov
The critic Alexei Khromov talks about a slightly drawn-out picture linking the writer‚Äôs books to Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs Shining.
On November 7, the film ‚ÄúDoctor Dream‚Äù by director Mike Flanegan started on Russian screens. The painting is based on the eponymous novel by Stephen King, which continues the plot of "Radiance."
Flanegan faced a very difficult task. Indeed, many people know the ‚ÄúShine‚Äù not only thanks to King‚Äôs novel - Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs film was no less legendary. And the director then greatly changed many storylines, and even the atmosphere of the original.
Surprisingly, the screen version of Doctor Sleep managed to link King's pitch with the visuals of Kubrick, and at the same time remained an independent work. Spoils the atmosphere only the director‚Äôs passion for drama, which too slows down the action.
The story of childhood injuries
After surviving at the Overlook Hotel, Danny Torrens moved with his mother south. He learned to control his telepathic powers, which he called the "radiance", and eventually figured out almost terrible visions. But years passed, and Danny never found himself in life and gradually drank himself up.



Everything changes when he moves to another city and begins to telepathically communicate with the girl Abra. As it turns out, a community of energy vampires has been operating in the country for a long time. They call themselves the "True Knot" and feed on the "radiance", pumping it out of the suffering of man. And they will surely hunt Abra.
The main advantage of ‚ÄúDoctor Sleep‚Äù King is that the author decided to understand the consequences of childhood injury. Indeed, many horror films, especially those dedicated to young characters, end on how the characters escape from a monster or maniac. But it is hard to imagine that such events will pass without a trace.
Therefore, the alcoholism of Danny Torrens and his loss in life is the most likely development of events. And the first third of the adaptation of Flanegan is closer to a completely vital drama, which everyone loved in King's work.



This, of course, greatly slows down the development of the plot, especially since for all the details of Danny‚Äôs life, there is still not enough screen time. Even the nickname "Doctor Dream" he gets as if in passing. But still, this approach allows the authors to better reveal the character, and fans of Ewan McGregor to enjoy his acting talent.
Acquaintance with the representatives of the ‚ÄúTrue Knot‚Äù at first takes place rather as a backdrop, and the lives of these heroes are not really shown. Most of them in the film will remain extras and cannon fodder, even though very bright Emily Alyn Lind and Zana McClarnon were invited to play Andy and Raven.



But their attention is drawn by their leader Rose-in-Hat. Rebecca Ferguson was just gorgeous. She manages to be both charming and frantic in the role of villain.
A successful cast even covers some of the weak turns of the script and the protractedness of individual scenes. Moreover, an excellent author works on the picture.
Horror and Stanley Kubrick
Mike Flanegan as director and screenwriter is the best thing that could happen to this picture. Even after the release of Oculus, he proved that he perfectly removes horrors. His "Ghosts of the House on the Hill" conquered everyone by combining drama and scary scenes. In addition, Flanegan has already managed to work with King on the adaptation of Gerald's Game.



The writer admitted * that he did not just like the script of Doctor Sleep. Flanegan even managed to ‚Äúreconcile‚Äù King with the film ‚ÄúRadiance,‚Äù which the author of the novels strongly criticized. * Source: Stephen King says Doctor Sleep film ‚Äòredeems‚Äô Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs The Shining
The thing is that the director often openly quotes the stunning visual part of the previous picture. The new film has dozens of references, especially in the introduction and the finale, and even directly re-shot famous scenes from the classics. And this, of course, will win fans of Kubrick.
At the same time, the director does not copy the great predecessor, he regularly reminds the viewer that his passion is horror. Therefore, the bulk of the film is built in the best traditions of the genre without going into a psychological thriller. This is the very confrontation between good and evil, seasoned with human tragedy, which King loves so much.



But Flanegan does not try to scare only terrible effects and screamers (although they are also enough here). He creates excellent suspense, shooting in long shots and letting the actors play to the full.
And the shooting will please the aesthetes at all: in mystical moments, the picture is regularly turned over, forcing the viewer to get confused where the floor is and where is the ceiling, a successful installation very unusual connects the scenes, and the famous camera angles from ‚ÄúThe Shining‚Äù, when the camera shoots directly from above, were made more interesting. Moreover, unlike the chamber predecessor, the new film has a place to turn around.

The main drawback of the picture can be considered only its timing. For the better, both a decrease and an increase would work. If the film turned out to be shorter, the audience would not have the opportunity to get bored on too long scenes of the experiences of the characters. And if he was turned into a mini-series for five hours, then the authors could better reveal all the characters and tell in detail about their lives.
But ‚ÄúDoctor Dream‚Äù lasts two and a half hours, which is too much for a regular horror movie and not enough for a large-scale drama in the spirit of ‚ÄúGhosts of a House on a Hill‚Äù. But nevertheless, the advantages of the picture more than pay for some awkwardness.
